Award.AwardTitle: Seeking Sustainable and Efficient Energy Production and Use In a Changing World

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds work that will help us understand how federal regulations affect oil and natural gas markets in the United States. The project will proceed in several stages. First, the research team will catalog and characterize federal regulations that affect the development of petroleum and natural gas resources. Second, they will develop methods to estimate the effects of these regulations on industry, including the possible impact of changing existing regulation. Third, they will estimate the effects of these regulations on the public, including consumers of oil and natural gas. The final part of the project will examine the overall welfare economics of lifting and/or lessening federal regulation in this sector of the economy.

The project is directly relevant to issues facing the US Department of Energy, and the results will help policymakers make judgements about the appropriate types and levels of regulation in this economic sector.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant led to the tabulation of all regulations in the last decade that affected directly or indirectly the upstream portion of the oil and gas sector and then the conduct of six case studies from those regulations to analyze the costs and benefits of modifications and repeal of these rules.

We found approximately 100 regulations in the last decade preceding the Trump Administration that meet our definition of regulations affecting the oil and gas sector. Of the six regulations we looked at closely, some were actually modified by the Trump administration, one was repealed (and in the courts) and some were not addressed. Ranking these six by the cost savings of repeal (The Trump administration's preferred metric) and comparing that ranking to the traditional net benefits of repeal criterion, we find no correlation. We also find that by changing a few parameters in the Regulatory Impact Analyses for these rules, net benefits of repeal can be switched from negative to positive.  The most important parameter was the social cost of carbon.  Further, we examined the Trump administration's RIA's in support of repealing and modifying some of the six rules we choose for case studies.  We found that, in contrast to the original RIA's from the Obama administration, the new RIAs were generally less transparent.  We also found that modifications of some of the rules proposed by the administration were responsive to industry complaints, but that not all major complaints led to rule modifications.
